q1.question:
This modern-day country was outraged by the Council of Blood being imposed as its ruler, as
well as by the Tenth Penny tax. It allied with the "Sea Beggars" against Spanish governors such
as the Duke of Alba and won its independence in the Eighty Years War. For 10 points, name this
country where William the Silent reigned over land reclaimed from the sea via dikes.

This woman was implicated in a fraud known as the Affair of the Diamond Necklace. She
became known as "the widow Capet" following the death of her husband, Louis XVI. For 10
points, name this queen of France who legendarily dismissed a crowd of peasants crying out for
bread by saying "let them eat cake."

These people believed that people who died by drowning went to an underworld ruled by
Tlaloc (pr. tuh-LAH-lock) rather than the main underworld, Mictlan (pr. MIKT-lon). These
people believed that an eagle with a snake in its mouth had alighted on a cactus, telling them
where to build their capital. For 10 points, name this group that worshipped Quetzalcoatl (pr.
KET-sul-coh-AH-tul).

A sculpture group by this artist depicts an incident in which Eustache de Saint Pierre led six
men into captivity in 1347 following a battle with Edward III. The most iconic piece by this
sculptor was part of his exhibition The Gates of Hell and represents Dante planning the Divine
Comedy. For 10 points, name this sculptor of The Burghers of Calais and The Thinker.

This industry became involved in a scandal during the Spanish-American War when it
supplied poor-quality goods to Nelson Miles's troops in Puerto Rico. This industry was later
fictionalized as mistreating immigrant Jurgis Rudkus, leading Theodore Roosevelt to support the
Pure Food and Drug Act. For 10 points, name this industry which Upton Sinclair targeted in The
Jungle.

Two sports teams based in this country met in the Naismith Cup. In 1993, a team based in this
country employed John Olerud and Paul Molitor. This country's lesser-known national sport is
lacrosse, and its football league contests the Grey Cup every year. For 10 points, name this
former home of the NBA's Grizzlies and current home of baseball's Blue Jays.

This man personally financed and organized a rescue mission for employees of Electronic
Data Systems who were imprisoned in Iran. He chose James Stockdale as his running mate in a
Presidential election that saw him widely mocked for buying network airtime to display a series
of charts. For 10 points, name this independent who received twenty percent of the vote in 1992.

Emmanuel Timoni first described a method of preventing this disease, which Mary Worley
Montagu famously was guarded against in Constantinople. Cotton Mather wrote in support of
inoculation against this disease, which was proved feasible in England by Edward Jenner. For 10
points, name this formerly devastating disease which was eliminated by the 1990s.

The chief justice during this event, William Stoughton, controversially allowed "spectral
evidence" to be introduced, an action later condemned by Increase Mather. These events began
with accusations against the slave Tituba and resulted in dozens of executions by hanging and
pressing. For 10 points, name this episode of mass hysteria in 1692 Massachusetts.

Much of the groundwork for this institution was laid at the San Francisco Conference by spy
Alger Hiss. At this institution, Valerian Zorin was told “don’t wait for the translation” by Adlai
Stevenson, who served as U.S. ambassador to this institution under John F. Kennedy. For 10
points, name this successor to the League of Nations which meets in New York.

(TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) The Qing Dynasty was founded by what ethnic group from the north of China, which
mandated that all Han Chinese wear their hair in queues?

tossup.question:
When setting up skeletons of this species for display, museums frequently used the skull of
Camarasaurus. That practice perpetuated Othniel Charles Marsh's belief that this species was not
identical to a skeleton unearthed in 1885. For 10 points, identify this dinosaur species which
Marsh erroneously identified as separate from the fictitious "brontosaurus."

bonus.question: The apatosaurus flourished during what middle period of the Mesozoic era?

tossup.question:
This man hid out at Liliesleaf Farm after the Treason Trial, where he organized the militant
group Spear of the Nation. He gave the "I Am Prepared to Die" speech at the Rivonia Trial,
which led to his lengthy imprisonment on Robben Island. For 10 points, name this man who
ultimately worked with F.W. de Klerk to end the apartheid system in South Africa.

bonus.question:
Mandela's Spear of the Nation was the paramilitary wing of what anti-apartheid group,
which has been the governing political party of South Africa since 1994?

tossup.question:
Jacob Bernoulli discovered that this number is the "force of interest," the limit of the interest
accruable on a dollar by increasing the frequency of compounding. A 1727 paper on the
explosive force of cannons introduced this number as the base of the natural logarithm. For 10
points, identify this mathematical constant named for its Swiss popularizer.

bonus.question:
Euler (pr. OY-ler) also established graph theory in an attempt to solve the problem
involving seven of what kind of structure in Königsberg?

tossup.question:
This composer incorporated "Springfield Mountain" and "Camptown Races," along with
excerpts from the Gettysburg Address, into his World War II patriotic piece A Lincoln Portrait.
He scored ballets about Billy the Kid and about pioneers building a farmhouse in western
Pennsylvania. For 10 points, name this composer of Appalachian Spring.

bonus.question:
As part of the same biographical project that led Copland to create A Lincoln Portrait,
Virgil Thomson set poems by what author of Leaves of Grass?

tossup.question:
This device was originally named for doctor Antoine Louis. The "tricoteuse" (pr. TRICK-awtooz) were women who knitted next to this object. This object was used on up to forty thousand
people at the order of Maximilien Robespierre, who found himself subject to it in 1794. For 10
points, name this item which was used to execute Louis XVI and others during the French
Revolution.

bonus.question:
The guillotine was originally used to equalize execution methods for nobles and
members of what group, the peasant section of France in the Estates-General?

tossup.question:
This system was restored following the overthrow of Hippias (pr. HIP-ee-uss), after which its
central feature was the boulé (pr. BOO-lay). This system involved citizens being arranged into
demes (pr. DEEMZ) by Cleisthenes (pr. CLICE-thuh-neez). For 10 points, identify this
political system used in classical Athens, which inspired similar vote-based systems in the
modern world.

bonus.question:
Members of the boulé were selected by what method, also used to pick the tenth of an
army that Romans "decimated" and the date of the massacre of Jews in the Book of Esther?

tossup.question:
This language was used to write The Incoherence of the Philosophers, which was rebutted
with The Incoherence of the Incoherence. This was the language used by the medieval
philosopher Averroes (pr. AA-vuh-ROE-ez) and other writers based at Córdoba (pr. COREdoh-buh). For 10 points, name this language through which many Greek and Latin texts passed
to Europe.

bonus.question:
Which other Semitic language, which was the language which Jesus spoke, was
featured in the Mel Gibson directed film, The Passion of the Christ?

tossup.question:
In the twentieth century, some groups modified this holiday to use a "cup of Miriam" to
symbolize women and an orange to symbolize homosexuals. This holiday also changed in the
twelfth century, when its service was collected as the "haggadah" (pr. hah-GUH-duh). For 10
points, name this Jewish holiday on which the "seder" (pr. SAY-dur) meal includes matzah
(MAHT-suh).

bonus.question:
What book of the Bible, in which Moses leads the Jews out of Egypt, is the focus of
Passover?

questions.question:
In the history of the Caribbean islands, who or what was the…
Style of music originating in Trinidad practiced by Harry Belafonte (pr. beh-luh-FON-tay)
and Lord Invader?

Country that colonized Martinique (pr. mar-tin-EEK), Guadeloupe (pr. gwah-duh-LOOP),
and Haiti?

Group including St. Croix (pr. CROY), St. John, and St. Thomas that has U.S. and British
sections?
Crop harvested under the “gang system” in the most harsh form of slavery?
Regiment led by Leonard Wood and Theodore Roosevelt that captured San Juan Hill?
Island where Maurice Bishop's execution led to the American Operation Urgent Fury in 1983?
British colony where the Maroon Wars involving escaped slaves took place?
Dominican dictator assassinated with American approval in 1961?

The emancipation of the world's largest serf population…
Occurred in what empire, which was ultimately ended by the deposition of Tsar Nicholas II?
Began in what year, also the year Abraham Lincoln's Presidency and the Civil War started?
Was instigated by what tsar, who was assassinated twenty years later?

Ended the landlord veto over serfs engaging in what practice, the subject of the American
court case Loving v. Virginia?
Was part of the fallout from Russia's defeat by Britain, France, and Turkey in what war?

Led radicals to support what political position that characterized the Nechaevists, Land and
Liberty, and The People's Will?
Set up what system of elected provincial councils?
Required that former serfs do what for forty-nine years?
answer: submit redemption payments to former owners

questions.question:
The American city of Philadelphia was…
The initial capital of what colony, set up as a religious refuge?
The place where what document, written by Thomas Jefferson, was signed in July 1776?
Where what kite-flying inventor of bifocals published the Gazette?

Where the first American instance of what kind of institution, which now includes New York
Presbyterian and Cedars-Sinai, was established?
Named for the “brotherly love” exhibited by what pacifist Christian sect?
Lost to the British in September 1777 following Howe's defeat of Washington at what creek?

The site of a 1793 epidemic of what disease, which Walter Reed combatted at the Panama
Canal?
Where what cartoon, featuring an eight-segmented snake, was published in 1754?

parts:
(30 pts) Letters leaked by Henry Simpson McComb first exposed this company's actions to the
New York Sun. This company was organized by George Train and Thomas (20 pts)

Durant, and
it began a cozy relationship with Congress following the installation of Oakes (10 pts)

Ames as
its president. It held an inflated contract with the Union Pacific railroad. For 10 points, name this
company at the center of an 1872 Grant administration scandal involving political graft.

(30 pts) A succession war named for this area began on the death of Maximilian Joseph in 1777
and was also known as the "potato war." Motifs from Wagner (pr. VOG-ner) operas are
used to decorate the (20 pts)

Neuschwanstein (pr. noy-SHVON-shtine) Castle in this region,
which was built by its (10 pts)

"Mad" king Ludwig II. For 10 points, name this southeastern German
state and historic kingdom, where many German Catholics and the city of Munich can be found.

(30 pts) The protagonist of this TV show insisted that if Ronald Reagan dyed his hair, he only did
so "to show his strength to the Communists," and had his faith in the Republican Party
tested when he discovered that (20 pts)

George W. Bush had a limp handshake. An episode of
this show is about a plot to steal Santa Anna's (10 pts)

wooden leg on its way back to Mexico, and
in another, former governor Ann Richards dates Bill. For 10 points, name this former FOX
cartoon about Arlen, Texas.

(30 pts) These places grew up after World War II on the "Levittown" model. These places were
the destination of "white flight," and attempts to combine their (20 pts)

school systems with
majority-black districts in the 1970s led to "busing" programs. The automotive
dependence of these places is criticized for contributing to (10 pts)

"sprawl." For 10 points, name
these places to which middle-class Americans shifted after the 1950s, from which many people
commute to cities.

(30 pts) This movement's victory was secured at the Battle of Vertières (pr. VAIR-tee-air). This
movement was started by the "houngan" Dutty Boukman, and it was partially betrayed to
Charles (20 pts)

Leclerc. Following this movement's success, its victors immediately split into
factions supporting either Henri (10 pts)

Christophe or Jean-Jacques Dessalines. For 10 points,
name this successful slave rebellion which was initially led by Toussaint L'Ouverture (pr. TOOsahn ver-TOR).

(30 pts) These items may have been named for the shipworkers on Hog Island who enjoyed them
in the Philadelphia area. Another name for these items is attributed to Dominic Conti, who
took inspiration from viewing the (20 pts)

Fenian Ram on display in a museum. Less certain
origins for this object’s names include the New England term (10 pts)

“grinder” and the New
York area “hero.” For 10 points, name this lunch food popularized by Italian-Americans and now
served as a “five-dollar footlong.”

(30 pts) This man coined the name "scissors crisis" during the period of the New Economic
Policy. He also created the term "degenerated workers state" to summarize his views on
what the (20 pts)

Soviet Union became following his deposition as head of the Red Army. He
was ultimately killed in (10 pts)

Mexico by Ramon Mercador. For 10 points, name this member of
the Left Opposition who was outmaneuvered by Joseph Stalin for leadership of the USSR.

(30 pts) Frank Morris and the Anglin brothers left fake heads behind at this location in 1962.
From 1969 to 1971, this location was occupied in a political protest by the Indians of All
Tribes. Burt (20 pts)

Lancaster played the title role in a film about Robert Stroud, the
"birdman" of this place. Officially, no one ever (10 pts)

escaped from this place, assuming Morris
and Anglin drowned before reaching Angel Island. For 10 points, name this former prison and
island off San Francisco.

(30 pts) (TIEBREAKER EXAMPLE QUESTION) This king was the beneficiary of the original Act of Supremacy. He raised funds for the
middle part of his reign by dissolving nearly all monasteries in his kingdom, with the
assistance of his first administrator Thomas (20 pts)

Wolsey. This king was the father of
Edward VI, (10 pts)

Mary I, and Elizabeth I. For 10 points, name this king whose attempt to divorce
Catherine of Aragon triggered the English Reformation and his five subsequent marriages.
